user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtMem2HexFile:
```c
bool UtMem2HexFile(const void *Memory, const char *Filename, uint32 Length)
{
    FILE * fp;
    uint32 i;
    uint32 j;

    if ((fp = fopen(Filename, "w")))
    {
        for (i = 0; i < Length; i += 16)
        {
            fprintf(fp, "   %06lX: ", (unsigned long)i);
            for (j = 0; j < 16; j++)
            {
                if ((i + j) < Length)
                    fprintf(fp, "%02X ", ((uint8 *)Memory)[i + j]);
                else
                    fprintf(fp, "   ");
            }
            fprintf(fp, " ");
            for (j = 0; j < 16; j++)
            {
                if ((i + j) < Length)
                    fprintf(fp, "%c", isprint(((uint8 *)Memory)[i + j]) ? ((uint8 *)Memory)[i + j] : '.');
            }
            fprintf(fp, "\n");
        }
        fclose(fp);
        return true;
    }
    else
    {
        printf("UtMem2HexFile: Error Opening File: %s, %s\n", Filename, strerror(errno));
        UtAssert_True(false, "UtMem2HexFile: Error Opening File");
        return false;
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtMem2HexFile:
typedef uint8_t   uint8
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
...
#define UtAssert_True(Expression, __VA_ARGS__) UtAssertEx(Expression,UtAssert_GetContext(),__FILE__,__LINE__,__VA_ARGS__)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The only places that potentially violate Rule 8.13 (pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible) are the explicit casts that remove the const-qualification from the Memory parameter: each occurrence of ((uint8 *)Memory)[i + j]. Other pointer uses in this function do not need investigation for this rule: the function parameters are declared const where appropriate (const void *Memory, const char *Filename); FILE *fp is required by the C stdio API; the cast to (unsigned long) for i is not a pointer-related issue; calls to library functions (fopen, fprintf, printf, strerror, isprint) follow their documented signatures. Therefore only the shown cast-away-const usages should be investigated.
